posts.title: Foundational stack that works for most people
posts.excerpt: Multivitamin, omega-3, magnesium, and vitamin D — how to position them responsibly.

content.text: A foundational supplement stack isn't meant to replace a good diet, but to fill the gaps created by soil depletion, stress, and lifestyle factors.

In the modern world, getting every nutrient from whole foods alone can be a challenge. A foundational supplement stack isn't meant to replace a good diet, but to fill the gaps created by soil depletion, stress, and lifestyle factors.

Think of this as your nutritional insurance policy. A good multi provides a broad spectrum of vitamins and minerals in their most bioavailable forms. Look for brands that use methyl-folate instead of folic acid and avoid synthetic fillers.

Essential for brain health, heart function, and reducing systemic inflammation. Most people have a high ratio of Omega-6 to Omega-3; supplementing with a clean, third-party tested fish oil can help restore this balance.
Often called the 'sunshine vitamin,' D3 is crucial for immune function and bone density. Pairing it with K2 ensures that calcium is directed to your bones rather than accumulating in your arteries.
Always consult with a healthcare professional before starting a new supplement regimen. Individual needs vary based on age, health status, and existing medications.

posts.title: Creatine: benefits, dosing, and hydration callouts
posts.excerpt: Template section for strength, cognition, and cycling guidance.

content.text: Creatine monohydrate is one of the most well-researched supplements in existence. While primarily known for its role in strength and power output, its benefits extend far into cognitive health and cellular energy management.

It helps regenerate ATP, the primary energy currency of your cells. This allows for higher intensity during workouts and faster recovery between sets. Beyond the gym, research shows creatine may support memory and focus in sleep-deprived individuals.

posts.title: Adaptogens you can theme per audience
posts.excerpt: Ashwagandha, rhodiola, and L-theanine — angles for stress, focus, and sleep.

content.text: Adaptogens are a unique class of herbs that help the body manage stress by modulating the HPA axis. Depending on your niche (busy executives, parents, or athletes), you can frame these herbs differently.
Renowned for its ability to lower serum cortisol levels, Ashwagandha is the 'heavy hitter' for stress-prone populations. It's best taken in the evening to support restful sleep.
